diamondiso.js.doc: Use this method to place an entity in an isometric grid.

particles.js.name: Particles
particles.js.trigger: ParticleEnd - when the particle animation has finished
doc: Based on Parcycle by Mr. Speaker, licensed under the MIT, Ported by Leo Koppelkamm
**This is canvas only & won't do anything if the browser doesn't support it!**
To see how this works take a look in https://github.com/craftyjs/Crafty/blob/master/src/particles.js

particles.js.name: .particles
particles.js.param: options - Map of options that specify the behavior and look of the particles.
example: // Angle is calculated clockwise: 12pm is 0deg, 3pm is 90deg etc.
// Only applies when fastMode is off, specifies how sharp the gradients are drawn
// How many frames should this last
// Will draw squares instead of circle gradients

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio
doc: Add sound files and play them. Chooses best format for browser support.
Due to the nature of HTML5 audio, three types of audio files will be
required for cross-browser capabilities. These formats are MP3, Ogg and WAV.
When sound was not muted on before pause, sound will be unmuted after unpause.
When sound is muted Crafty.pause() does not have any effect on sound
The maximum number of sounds that can be played simultaneously is defined by Crafty.audio.maxChannels.  The default value is 7.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.supports
sound.js.param: extension - A file extension to check audio support for
sound.js.doc: Return true if the browser thinks it can play the given file type, otherwise false

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.create
sound.js.sign: public this Crafty.audio.create(String id, String url)
param: id - A string to refer to sounds
url - A string pointing to the sound file
doc: Creates an audio asset with the given id and resource.  `Crafty.audio.add` is a more flexible interface that allows cross-browser compatibility.
If the sound file extension is not supported, returns false; otherwise, returns the audio asset.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.add
sign: public this Crafty.audio.add(String id, String url)
public this Crafty.audio.add(String id, Array urls)
param: id - A string to refer to sounds
url - A string pointing to the sound file
urls - Array of urls pointing to different format of the same sound, selecting the first that is playable
map - key-value pairs where the key is the `id` and the value is either a `url` or `urls`
doc: Loads a sound to be played. Due to the nature of HTML5 audio,
three types of audio files will be required for cross-browser capabilities.
These formats are MP3, Ogg and WAV.
Passing an array of URLs will determine which format the browser can play and select it over any other.
Accepts an object where the key is the audio name and
either a URL or an Array of URLs (to determine which type to use).
The ID you use will be how you refer to that sound when using `Crafty.audio.play`.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.play
sign: public this Crafty.audio.play(String id, Number repeatCount)
public this Crafty.audio.play(String id, Number repeatCount, Number volume)
param: id - A string to refer to sounds
repeatCount - Repeat count for the file, where -1 stands for repeat forever.
volume - volume can be a number between 0.0 and 1.0
doc: Will play a sound previously added by using the ID that was used in `Crafty.audio.add`.
Has a default maximum of 5 channels so that the same sound can play simultaneously unless all of the channels are playing.
*Note that the implementation of HTML5 Audio is buggy at best.*
example: Crafty.audio.play("explosion",1,0.5); //play sound once with volume of 50%

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.setChannels
sound.js.param: n - The maximum number of channels

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.remove
sound.js.param: id - A string to refer to sounds
doc: Will stop the sound and remove all references to the audio object allowing the browser to free the memory.
If no id is given, all sounds will be removed.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.stop
sound.js.doc: Stops any playing sound. if id is not set, stop all sounds which are playing

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.toggleMute
doc: Mute or unmute every Audio instance that is playing. Toggles between
pausing or playing depending on the state.
example: //toggle mute and unmute depending on current state

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.mute
sound.js.doc: Mute every Audio instance that is playing.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.unmute
sound.js.doc: Unmute every Audio instance that is playing.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.pause
sound.js.param: {string} id - The id of the audio object to pause
sound.js.doc: Pause the Audio instance specified by id param.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.unpause
sound.js.param: {string} id - The id of the audio object to unpause
sound.js.doc: Resume playing the Audio instance specified by id param.

sound.js.name: Crafty.audio.togglePause
sound.js.param: {string} id - The id of the audio object to pause/
sound.js.doc: Toggle the pause status of the Audio instance specified by id param.

text.js.name: Text
text.js.trigger: Invalidate - when the text is changed
doc: Component to make a text entity.
By default, text will have the style "10px sans-serif".
Note 1: An entity with the text component is just text! If you want to write text
inside an image, you need one entity for the text and another entity for the image.
More tips for writing text inside an image: (1) Use the z-index (from 2D component)
to ensure that the text is on top of the image, not the other way around; (2)
use .attach() (from 2D component) to glue the text to the image so they move and
rotate together.
Note 2: For DOM (but not canvas) text entities, various font settings (like
text-decoration and text-align) can be set using `.css()` (see DOM component). But
you cannot use `.css()` to set the properties which are controlled by `.textFont()`
or `.textColor()` -- the settings will be ignored.
Note 3: If you use canvas text with glyphs that are taller than standard letters, portions of the glyphs might be cut off.

text.js.name: .text
text.js.param: text - String of text that will be inserted into the DOM or Canvas element.
doc: This method will update the text inside the entity.
If you need to reference attributes on the entity itself you can pass a function instead of a string.
example: Crafty.e("2D, DOM, Text").attr({ x: 100, y: 100 }).text("Look at me!!");
Crafty.e("2D, Canvas, Text").attr({ x: 100, y: 100 }).text("Look at me!!");

text.js.name: .textColor
param: color - The color in hexadecimal
strength - Level of opacity
text.js.doc: Modify the text color and level of opacity.
example: Crafty.e("2D, DOM, Text").attr({ x: 100, y: 100 }).text("Look at me!!")
Crafty.e("2D, Canvas, Text").attr({ x: 100, y: 100 }).text('Look at me!!')

text.js.name: .textFont
param: key - Property of the entity to modify
value - Value to set the property to
map - Object where the key is the property to modify and the value as the property value
doc: Use this method to set font property of the text entity.  Possible values are: type, weight, size, family, lineHeight, and variant.
When rendered by the canvas, lineHeight and variant will be ignored.

text.js.name: .unselectable
doc: This method sets the text so that it cannot be selected (highlighted) by dragging.
(Canvas text can never be highlighted, so this only matters for DOM text.)
Works by changing the css property "user-select" and its variants.
example: Crafty.e("2D, DOM, Text").text('This text cannot be highlighted!').unselectable();

loader.js.name: Crafty.assets
doc: An object containing every asset used in the current Crafty game.
The key is the URL and the value is the `Audio` or `Image` object.
If loading an asset, check that it is in this object first to avoid loading twice.

loader.js.name: Crafty.asset
loader.js.trigger: NewAsset - After setting new asset - Object - key and value of new added asset.
sign: public void Crafty.asset(String key, Object asset)
param: key - asset url.
asset - Audio` or `Image` object.
key - asset url.
doc: Add new asset to assets object.
Get asset from assets object.
example: var asset = Crafty.asset(key); //object with key and value fields

loader.js.name: Crafty.image_whitelist
loader.js.doc: A list of file extensions that can be loaded as images by Crafty.load

loader.js.name: Crafty.loader
loader.js.sign: public void Crafty.load(Array assets, Function onLoad[, Function onProgress, Function onError])
param: assets - Array of assets to load (accepts sounds and images)
onLoad - Callback when the assets are loaded
onProgress - Callback when an asset is loaded. Contains information about assets loaded
onError - Callback when an asset fails to load
doc: Preloader for all assets. Takes an array of URLs and
adds them to the `Crafty.assets` object.
Files with suffixes in `image_whitelist` (case insensitive) will be loaded.
If `Crafty.support.audio` is `true`, files with the following suffixes `mp3`, `wav`, `ogg` and `mp4` (case insensitive) can be loaded.
The `onProgress` function will be passed on object with information about
the progress including how many assets loaded, total of all the assets to
load and a percentage of the progress.
{ loaded: j, total: total, percent: (j / total * 100) ,src:src})
`onError` will be passed with the asset that couldn't load.
When `onError` is not provided, the onLoad is loaded even some assets are not successfully loaded. Otherwise, onLoad will be called no matter whether there are errors or not.

math.js.name: Crafty.math.Vector2D
doc: Vector2D uses the following form:
<x, y>
param: {Vector2D|Number=0} x
{Number=0} y

math.js.name: .add
math.js.doc: Adds the passed vector to this vector

math.js.name: .angleBetween
doc: Calculates the angle between the passed vector and this vector, using <0,0> as the point of reference.
Angles returned have the range (, ].

math.js.name: .angleTo
math.js.doc: Calculates the angle to the passed vector from this vector, using this vector as the point of reference.

math.js.name: .clone
math.js.doc: Creates and exact, numeric copy of this vector

math.js.name: .distance
math.js.doc: Calculates the distance from this vector to the passed vector.

math.js.name: .distanceSq
doc: Calculates the squared distance from this vector to the passed vector.
This function avoids calculating the square root, thus being slightly faster than .distance( ).

math.js.name: .divide
math.js.doc: Divides this vector by the passed vector.

math.js.name: .dotProduct
math.js.doc: Calculates the dot product of this and the passed vectors

math.js.name: .equals
math.js.doc: Determines if this vector is numerically equivalent to the passed vector.

math.js.name: .getNormal
math.js.doc: Calculates a new right-handed normal vector for the line created by this and the passed vectors.

math.js.name: .isZero
math.js.doc: Determines if this vector is equal to <0,0>

math.js.name: .magnitude
doc: Calculates the magnitude of this vector.
Note: Function objects in JavaScript already have a 'length' member, hence the use of magnitude instead.

math.js.name: .magnitudeSq
doc: Calculates the square of the magnitude of this vector.
This function avoids calculating the square root, thus being slightly faster than .magnitude( ).

math.js.name: .multiply
math.js.doc: Multiplies this vector by the passed vector

math.js.name: .negate
math.js.doc: Negates this vector (ie. <-x,-y>)

math.js.name: .normalize
doc: Normalizes this vector (scales the vector so that its new magnitude is 1)
For vectors where magnitude is 0, <1,0> is returned.

math.js.name: .scale
doc: Scales this vector by the passed amount(s)
If scalarY is omitted, scalarX is used for both axes
param: {Number} scalarX
{Number} [scalarY]

math.js.name: .scaleToMagnitude
math.js.doc: Scales this vector such that its new magnitude is equal to the passed value.

math.js.name: .setValues
math.js.doc: Sets the values of this vector using a passed vector or pair of numbers.
param: {Number|Vector2D} x
{Number} y

math.js.name: .subtract
math.js.doc: Subtracts the passed vector from this vector.

math.js.name: .toString
math.js.doc: Returns a string representation of this vector.

math.js.name: .translate
doc: Translates (moves) this vector by the passed amounts.
If dy is omitted, dx is used for both axes.
param: {Number} dx
{Number} [dy]

math.js.name: .tripleProduct
doc: Calculates the triple product of three vectors.
triple vector product = b(ac) - a(bc)
param: {Vector2D} a
{Vector2D} b
{Vector2D} c
math.js.return: {Vector2D} the triple product as a new vector

Matrix2D uses the following form, as per the whatwg.org specifications for canvas.transform():

[b, d, f]

{Number=0} b
{Number=0} c
{Number=1} d
{Number=0} e
{Number=0} f

math.js.name: .clone

math.js.name: .combine
doc: Multiplies this matrix with another, overriding the values of this matrix.
The passed matrix is assumed to be on the right-hand side.

math.js.name: .equals

math.js.name: .invert

math.js.name: .isIdentity

math.js.name: .isInvertible

time.js.name: .delay
param: callback - Method to execute after given amount of milliseconds
delay - Amount of milliseconds to execute the method
repeat - How often to repeat the delayed function. A value of 0 triggers the delayed
doc: function exactly once. A value n > 0 triggers the delayed function exactly n+1 times. A
value of -1 triggers the delayed function indefinitely.
The delay method will execute a function after a given amount of time in milliseconds.
It is not a wrapper for `setTimeout`.
If Crafty is paused, the delay is interrupted with the pause and then resume when unpaused
If the entity is destroyed, the delay is also destroyed and will not have effect.

DebugLayer.js.name: DebugCanvas
trigger: Draw - when the entity is ready to be drawn to the stage
NoCanvas - if the browser does not support canvas
doc: When this component is added to an entity it will be drawn by the DebugCanvas layer.
Crafty.debugCanvas.init() will be automatically called if it is not called already to initialize the canvas element.
To visualise an object's MBR, use "VisibleMBR".  To visualise a "Collision" object's hitbox, use "WiredHitBox" or "SolidHitBox".

DebugLayer.js.name: .debugAlpha
DebugLayer.js.param: alpha - The alpha level the component will be drawn with

DebugLayer.js.name: .debugFill
DebugLayer.js.param: fillStyle - The color the component will be filled with.  Defaults to "red". Pass the boolean false to turn off filling.

DebugLayer.js.name: .debugStroke
DebugLayer.js.param: strokeStyle - The color the component will be outlined with.  Defaults to "red".  Pass the boolean false to turn this off.

DebugLayer.js.name: DebugRectangle
doc: A component for rendering an object with a position and dimensions to the debug canvas.
var myEntity = Crafty.e("2D, DebugRectangle")
.debugStroke("green");
myEntity.debugRectangle(myEntity)

DebugLayer.js.name: .debugRectangle
DebugLayer.js.param: rect - an object with _x, _y, _w, and _h to draw
DebugLayer.js.doc: Sets the rectangle that this component draws to the debug canvas.

DebugLayer.js.name: VisibleMBR
doc: Adding this component to an entity will cause it's MBR to be drawn to the debug canvas.
The methods of DebugCanvas can be used to control this component's appearance.

DebugLayer.js.name: DebugPolygon
doc: For drawing a polygon to the debug canvas
The methods of DebugCanvas can be used to control this component's appearance -- by default it is neither filled nor outlined
For debugging hitboxes, use WiredHitBox or SolidHitBox.  For debugging MBR, use VisibleMBR

DebugLayer.js.name: .debugPolygon
DebugLayer.js.doc: Sets the polygon that this component renders to the debug canvas.

DebugLayer.js.name: WiredHitBox
doc: Adding this component to an entity with a Collision component will cause its collision polygon to be drawn to the debug canvas as an outline
The methods of DebugCanvas can be used to control this component's appearance.

DebugLayer.js.name: SolidHitBox
doc: Adding this component to an entity with a Collision component will cause its collision polygon to be drawn to the debug canvas, with a default alpha level of 0.7.
The methods of DebugCanvas can be used to control this component's appearance.
